Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Performance-Based Framework for Wind-Excited Multi-Story Buildings

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The current prescriptive design philosophy that relies simply on meeting requirements stipulated in standards is shifting towards a performance-based design (PBD) approach for achieving designs that rationally meet society's need for a safe built environment. Extensive research has facilitated the successful adoption of PBD in earthquake engineering, but the same cannot be said for wind engineering and wind hazard. Wind acts differently on buildings than the earthquake loading. Wind loading is of long duration and performance is more critical for human comfort than for the earthquake loading. Therefore, the need exists to pursue development of a framework that embraces the concepts of PBD during the design of building systems to resist severe wind events. This would offer designers of new buildings and retrofitters of existing buildings a means not only to rationally assess the performance of structures under winds, but also to communicate their results in a language that decision-makers can understand. A major hurdle to the widespread use of PBD procedures is their uncertain nature, which makes the iterations traditionally involved in a design process impractical. The uncertainties can be effectively addressed by the development of specific optimization schemes that can handle the size and diversity of real world applications.

This project will develop a PBD framework for multi-story wind excited buildings in order to optimally mitigate structural and non-structural damage. The methodology will explicitly account for the inevitable uncertainty that characterizes all aspects of structural response estimation to natural hazards. This goal will be achieved through the definition of an effective wind building performance model that will rationally assess damage and loss in terms of consequence and fragility functions. To drive the building performance, site-specific wind hazard models will be defined in terms of appropriate intensity measures for a range of wind events, e.g. synoptic winds and hurricanes. By identifying suitable aerodynamic models, interaction parameters will be defined for driving a simulation-centered plastic theorem-based framework that not only yields input engineering demand parameters for performance in wind, but also provides a full portrait of the post-yield behavior of the structural system. In order to achieve systems that optimally satisfy the performance objectives, the wind PBD problem will be formulated as a probabilistic optimization problem. By developing a general solution strategy capable of efficiently handling problems characterized by system-level probabilistic constraints and/or objective functions in terms of high-dimensional design variable vectors, an integrated PBD and optimization methodology will be defined that has the promise to revolutionize current wind engineering practices.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Wind engineering of multi-story to high-rise buildings is moving away from prescriptive approaches in favor of methodologies that are rooted in performance-based engineering. Many factors are contributing to this trend, ranging from the need for more sustainable and economical solutions to the desire of achieving higher and more predictable performance. Accordingly, the structural system – also referred to as the main wind force resisting system (MWFRS) – and the cladding need to be designed to meet objectives formulated in terms of explicit performance metrics. The resulting increase in the complexity of the design process makes optimization/automation a fundamental part of the performance-based wind engineering paradigm.

In response to this challenge, this project has resulted in the development of a state-of-the-art performance-based wind engineering (PBWE) methodology that can be applied to multi-story to high-rise buildings for the performance assessment of their MWFRS. The methodology explicitly accounts for all sources of uncertainty affecting the estimation of the structural and non-structural performance, while communicating the results in ways that can be understood by a diverse pool of decision-makers, owners and in general stakeholders. In particular, building performance is expressed in terms of direct economic losses (building repair and replacement) and indirect losses (repair time and unsafe placarding as well as business interruption losses). To establish the PBWE framework, site-specific wind hazard models were defined in terms of appropriate intensity measures for a full range of extreme wind events, i.e. extratropical winds and hurricanes. Models defining appropriate interaction parameters were established for translating the intensity measures into aerodynamic loads to be used in classic/simulation-based, elastic/inelastic structural response analysis. With respect to inelastic analysis of wind-excited structures, this project resulted in the development of new approaches based on the implementation of dynamic shakedown theory. A new class of strain-based solution algorithms were proposed for modeling within the context of concentrated and distributed plasticity. The models were successfully validated through comparison with established approaches. The massive computational speed-ups of these new approaches enabled inelastic response analyses to be directly coupled with general stochastic simulation-based schemes, therefore resulting in the introduction of a new generation of system-level PBWE frameworks where performance is estimated explicitly in terms of structural reliability and/or system-level structural/non-structural loss. This project also resulted in the introduction of new data-driven performance assessment frameworks that take advantage of the ever-growing monitoring of the response of high-rise buildings during severe wind events. Initial frameworks have been introduced based on the coupling of artificial intelligence, in the form of machine learning techniques, and data analytics. The framework enables efficient extraction and classification of important metrics for the performance assessment of the cladding system of high-rise structures. Application of the framework was carried out on data gathered during Typhoon Mangkhut that impacted Hong Kong and Shenzhen, providing valuable input regarding the performance of the cladding systems of this region. In parallel to these efforts, this project also resulted in the development of a number of performance-based design optimization (PBDO) procedures that can treat the high-dimensional design space of typical multi-story to high-rise buildings while describing performance through the system-level metrics evaluated through the PBWE framework of this this project. During the course of the project, the PBDO framework was extended to topology optimization. This project also resulted in new developments in the field of computational fluid dynamics (CFD) based aerodynamic shape optimization of the building profile. In this respect, advances in CFD driven surrogate-based optimization strategies were achieved that were validated through specific wind tunnel tests carried out in the University of Florida’s NHERI experimental facility. 

The proposed methodologies, observations and frameworks will enhance the competitiveness of the building design industry and result in a new generation of better performing buildings at reduced environmental and economic costs. The performance-based wind engineering methodologies promise to change the way multi-story to high-rise buildings are assessed and designed. The optimization algorithms introduced in this project will promote both efficient structural systems as well as building profiles that minimize the aerodynamic loads. Machine learning aided data analytics for extraction of information from health monitoring programs as well as observations of building cladding damage around the world promise to aid in enhancing the performance and robustness of cladding system and their condition assessment.
